Title: Using our selves in work with older people
Source: Being with Older People: A Systemic Approach
Abstract: © 2010 to Glenda Fredman, Eleanor Anderson, and Joshua Stott for the edited collection, and to the individual authors for their contributions.This chapter discusses dilemmas to use the life experiences, emotions, and therapeutic conversation that go through the people’s mind. It suggests a consideration of both professional and personal lives that makes a valuable contribution to work with older people. “Contexts”, means the many different backgrounds and circumstances that inform lives, such as our gender, religion, sexuality, and age, to name a few. It is believed that the emotions that is experienced offers an important information and are used as a resource, but are often struggled with knowing to make best use of them as Eleanor did in his work with Enid and Bill. The idea of practising as outsider witnesses to older people’s stories as one way encourages their sharing to be decentred, as well as using the practice of transparency. Decentred practice has encouraged the older person to focus and has ensured that sharing does not serve their personal agenda.
